body: Julie Davids and Elizabeth Bacon Collins affirmed their partnership yesterday at the Casino House of Roger Williams Park in Providence, R.I. Rebecca Subar and Walt Senterfitt, friends of the couple, led the commitment ceremony. Ms. Davids (above, left), is 37. She is the founder and executive director of the Community H.I.V./AIDS Mobilization
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Julie Davids, Liz Collins

body: Theater 'KIDS & YIDDISH: UNPLUCKED!,' a bilingual show by the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater, at the JCC in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, (800) 994-3347. Sunday and Nov. 25 and 27 at 11 a.m. Tickets: $20; 12 and under, $17. 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL,' by Troupe America, tonight at 7:30 and tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the LaGuardia Performing Arts

body: ARNOLD -- Ruth (nee Schwartz). Born December 26, 1921, in South Hampton, LI. Passed away at 84 years old on November 4, 2005, after a brief illness. Ruth is survived by her husband of 61 years, Joseph Arnold, of Manhattan, her son Richard of Los Angeles, CA, and daughter Deborah of Manhattan Beach, CA. Ruth grew up in what was then the tiny town of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ARNOLD, RUTH (NEE SCHWARTZ)

body: Kari Lois Leveton, a daughter of Marcia and David Leveton of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, is to be married today to Elias Abraham Lehrer, the son of Sheribel F. Rothenberg and Robert E. Lehrer of Chicago. Rabbi Reeve Robert Brenner will officiate at the 2941 Restaurant in Falls Church, Va. The bride, 30, teaches English at Seneca Ridge Middle School
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Kari Leveton, Elias Lehrer

body: A teenager was arrested for slashing two passengers with a folding knife on the B49 bus in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, the police said. The suspect, Alain Gurvil, 17, of East Flatbush, was charged with two counts of assault and one count of criminal possession of a weapon. The police said that Mr. Gurvil bumped into a 24-year-old man while they were
title: Youth Charged in Brooklyn Bus Slashings

body: The students leaned forward in padded metal chairs facing picture windows. From there they could see clear across Jamaica Bay and off into the Atlantic, too. title: In Citizenship Class, American Music Is a Universal Language

body: When the mayor of New York took a helicopter to Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, for a three-hour walking tour, one of his photo opportunities was at the sea wall along Sheepshead Bay, which officials told him was pockmarked by dangerous holes and sections on the verge of collapse. The mayor was John Lindsay, and the year was 1973. Decades later, the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH; A Bridge Not Quite Far Enough

body: All New York City's public beaches will be open for the swimming season today, according to health officials who are responsible for monitoring water conditions. The beaches include Orchard Beach in the Bronx; Brighton Beach, Coney Island and Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn; Rockaway Beach in Queens; and Midland Beach, South Beach and Wolf's Pond Park
title: City's Beaches Are Open for the Season

body: THE day he missed the deadline for a National Endowment for the Arts grant, Joshua Mehigan decided he had had enough. An unsung, gap-toothed composer of lyrical, sharply observed verse, Mr. Mehigan had had a run of uncommonly bad luck, even by the standards of luckless New York poets. It was February of last year. Mr. Mehigan, then 34, had broken
title: CITYPEOPLE; Finding the Verse in Adversity

body: Most surfers try to avoid sharks, jellyfish and wipeouts, but Rockaway surfers have long had to worry about another hazard -- summonses. Because state regulations have heavily restricted surfing at Rockaway Beach, wave riders trying to perfect their cutback, bottom-turn and nose-riding have also had to learn the fine art of stealth surfing and
title: Sand, Surf, and Now, Permission to Enjoy It; At Rockaway Beach, Catching Waves Without Worrying About Being Caught by the Police

body: LINK--May Ferkin. Died March 14, 2005 in her 100th year, a life filled with dignity and service. A retired attorney, now living in Lake Worth, FL and Milton, NY, she spent most of her adult life in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, NY. She was a Founding Member of the Manhattan Beach Community Group and its Secretary for the first 31 years of its
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LINK, MAY FERKIN

body: THE downside of last weekend's subway station fire has been well documented: rerouted trains, passenger confusion, crowded platforms and, worst of all, long, cold waits for trains. But now, a week after the signal room blaze that knocked out service on the C train and reduced service on the A, it may not be too soon to wonder: Is there any upside
